docs.lead_paragraph: DR. JOHN M. BOWEN, director of the Veterinary Medical Experiment Station for the University of Georgia's College of Veterinary Medicine, calls it a ''wonder drug.'' David K. Crossen, a drug analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, says it is ''the best anti-parasitic ever developed.'' And now another superlative is on the way: It may join the tiny number of animal drugs adapted to human use.

headline.main: A BOVINE DRUG THAT HELPS PEOPLE SEE

byline.original: By Robert Steyer; Robert Steyer writes on business from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: THE floundering farm economy is taking its toll on the drug, chemical and biotechnology companies that last year sold nearly $2 billion worth of products to treat, immunize or fatten American farm animals and pets. During the past five years, sales of drugs, vaccines, and feed additives have grown at the anemic rate of 1 percent a year, compared with average annual growth of 13 percent between 1975 and 1980, according to the Animal Health Institute, a trade group for companies in animal health care. But the gloomy sales statistics have had little dampening effect on research. Last year alone, Pfizer, Eli Lilly, Merck, and a slew of other companies spent $296.3 million - up 86 percent from 1980 - to find and develop new products, according to the institute.

byline.original: By Robert Steyer; Robert Steyer writes on business from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Institute on Drug Abuse, saying that the public needs to know more about cocaine, said today that there had been dramatic increases in cocaine-related injuries and deaths in recent years. Reports from medical examiners in 25 metropolitan areas show that 185 cocaine-related deaths were reported in 1981 and 580 in 1984, and that the incomplete count for 1985 stands at 563 and is expected to go higher after all the reports are received. The compilation was made public at a news conference today. Many of those people died of heart problems as a result of cocaine use, and the Government said it issued the statistics because of the publicity resulting from the recent cocaine-related deaths of Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star, and of Don Rogers, a defensive back for the Cleveland Browns football team. Both athletes were found to have died of cardiac arrest as a result of cocaine intoxication.

headline.main: U.S. SAYS COCAINE-RELATED DEATHS ARE RISING

byline.original: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The 209th session of the Legislature ended its main session of 1986 at 6:30 P.M. on July 3, with many of the most important bills of the year not passed until the final 24 hours in a nightlong meeting. One key issue still not resolved in this election year is a plan to subsidize elderly people for the purchase of prescription drugs. It is possible that lawmakers will return in the next month or two to pass such a plan if negotiators reach agreement. In addition, legislators are expected to convene at the end of the year to consider renewing taxes that finance the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and to change the state tax code to conform with expected revisions in the Federal code. These are the major actions of the session: The Budget The Legislature passed a $41.5 billion budget that increased spending by about 7 percent from the previous year while also putting into effect the second of three yearly tax cuts. For the first time in three decades, the budget reduced the state's annual short-term borrowing, which stood at $4.4 billion last year, cutting it by almost $1 billion under a complicated plan to restructure payments to state employees' pension funds.

headline.main: SUMMARY OF THE MAJOR ACTIONS TAKEN BY THE NEW YORK LEGISLATURE IN 1986

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration today banned the use of sulfite preservatives in fresh vegetables and fruits. Sulfites have been linked to 13 deaths and many illnesses, mainly among asthmatics. The ban, which had been expected after months of investigation and scientific testing, becomes effective Aug. 8. It will apply to retail sales in both food stores and restaurants. It is expected to have the its greatest effect in restaurants, because many have used sulfite-containing additives to keep vegetables and fruits fresh-looking. Incidents of allergic reactions to sulfites have increased in recent years along with the rise in popularity of salad bars.

headline.main: U.S. ISSUES BAN ON SULFITES' USE IN CERTAIN FOODS

byline.original: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Football League commissioner announced a new anti-drug program yesterday that calls for increased mandatory testing for all players as well as possible lifetime suspensions for those who repeatedly use illegal drugs. The program announced by Commissioner Pete Rozelle is the most far-reaching among the major professional sports leagues. It includes unannounced tests and counseling and temporary suspensions with reduced or no pay for players who test positive. Hospitalization would be required for those with serious drug problems. In response, the N.F.L. Players Association said it could not agree to the program because it involves substantial changes to a 1982 agreement between the union and representatives of team owners. The Players Association scheduled a press conference in San Francisco today to give a detailed response.
